awd_titl_txt: Program Support Office for the Interagency Ocean Observation Committee
awd_abstract_narration:
The PI's request funding to provide partial support for the Interagency Ocean Observation Committee (IOOC) support office hosted at the Consortium for Ocean Leadership (COL). The IOOC Support Office will continue to provide project management and meeting support services for the IOOC.

Interagency collaboration is essential to achieve ocean science and technology priorities and, in particular, for planning and coordination of an ocean observation system. The IOOC support office provides administrative assistance to the federal agencies on all of the IOOS planning activities. An IOOC that is able to effectively support these goals will make meaningful contributions to broader societal goals related to climate, maritime operations, natural hazards, national security, public health, ecosystems, and natural resources.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Through FY21, the IOOC continued executing its requirements via expert task teams addressing critical needs for ocean observing systems. Support staff worked with IOOC leadership to organize OceanObs?19 and generate pathways for its follow-on activities and programs.  The decadal conference galvanized the global ocean observing community to address wide-ranging scientific and technological challenges. The IOOC also continued its successful implementation of executive and legislative requirements set by the National Ocean Policy, Integrated Coastal and Ocean Observing Act, Coordinated Ocean Observations and Research Act of 2020, and Office of Science and Technology Policy.

IOOC task teams made several major accomplishments. These teams are designed to provide subject matter expertise on a particular ocean observing topic. The task teams are an instrument for the committee to take on ocean observing issues that require more time than allocated in the bimonthly meetings. The IOOC supported three task teams during the reporting period: Metrics for Ocean Observing Systems, Biology-Integrating Core to Essential Variables (Bio-ICE), and Ocean Societal Indicators (OSI). IOOC leadership and staff also supported past task teams which have been transformed into community efforts such as the Underwater Glider User Group and the Animal Telemetry Network.

In addition to coordinating the IOOC Task Teams and community efforts, staff planned and executed OceanObs?19, part of a decadal conference series, which was held September 16-20, 2019 in Honolulu, Hawaii. OceanObs?19 galvanized over 1500 members of the global ocean observing community to investigate how the community meets future user needs (information), improves the delivery of products across the globe (interoperability), advances technology and services (innovation), and balances needs, capabilities, and knowledge worldwide (integration).

  • The Metrics for Ocean Observing Systems Task Team helps monitor and evaluate the status of U.S. observing activities at-large, which can then be used to assess IOOS and determine how adjustments to smaller programs can improve the system. These metrics should reflect indicators related to essential observing variables (EOVs)?physical, chemical, or biological?to help understand how well elements of the ocean domain are observed in time and space, determine vulnerabilities and opportunities in observing systems, and inform management and policy decisions to promote oceanographic research and operations.
  • The Biology-Integrating Core to Essential Variables (Bio-ICE) Task Team will help advance the integration of biological observations from local, regional and federal sources using best practices to inform national needs and ultimately feed seamlessly into the Global Ocean Observing System, as appropriate. To accomplish this goal the task team will focus on marine mammals and corals, to: 1) Reconcile the IOOS core biological variables with GOOS Essential Ocean Variables (EOVs) and the Group on Earth Observations? Essential Biodiversity Variables (EBVs), identifying where there are clear synergies in terms of spatial and temporal observing requirements and existing observation infrastructure and delivery including best practices/standards. 2) Identify and improve pathways for data flow for observations of these variables from both the Regional Associations and Federal sources into IOOS. Focus will be on identifying and implementing best practices surrounding standardized data collection and delivery adhering to the FAIR and CARE data principles.
  • The Ocean Societal Indicators (OSI) Task Team is seeking to increase our understanding of ocean and coastal systems and to improve science-based products and services for decision-making. The team will accomplish these objectives by leveraging existing observing programs that are conducting integrated observations (e.g. plankton/fish) to include socioeconomic and sociocultural indicators. Activities described in this scope of work will be consistent with the outcomes OceanObs?19, the UN Decade for Ocean Science and Sustainable Development, and the UN Sustainable Development Goals.
  • Underwater Glider User Group (UG2) is a product of the IOOC Glider Task Team and their community convenings. This user group was developed as a community-based coalition aimed at bolstering scientific collaboration and information/resource sharing for glider operators, data users, manufacturers, academia, and government agencies.
  • The Animal Telemetry Network (ATN) structure was initially developed though the past IOOC ATN Task Team. Now, the ATN has become a fully integrated project under the U.S. IOOS. The operational ATN provides a mechanism to facilitate and empower an alliance among Federal, industry, academic, state, local, tribal, and non‐Federal organizations to coordinate aquatic animal telemetry infrastructure and operations.
  • OceanObs?19 resulted in an extensive list of recommendations which feed into a Living Action Plan and a host of Community White Papers outlining the priorities for the next decade, opportunities for strengthening end-user engagement, and concepts for better integration of global ocean observing.

In general, Ocean Leadership served as the neutral source for analyses and briefs and provided full-time professional project management of the Interagency Ocean Observation Committee (IOOC).  Ocean Leadership?s staff completed actions under the White House Subcommittee on Ocean Science and Technology (SOST), fulfilled executive and congressional IOOC mandates, and addressed some of the growing challenges facing the ocean science and technology community. 


Last Modified: 01/12/2022
Modified by: Kristen Yarincik

Through FY21, the IOOC continued executing its requirements via expert task teams addressing critical needs for ocean observing systems. Support staff worked with IOOC leadership to organize OceanObs?19 and generate pathways for its follow-on activities and programs.  The decadal conference galvanized the global ocean observing community to address wide-ranging scientific and technological challenges. The IOOC also continued its successful implementation of executive and legislative requirements set by the National Ocean Policy, Integrated Coastal and Ocean Observing Act, Coordinated Ocean Observations and Research Act of 2020, and Office of Science and Technology Policy.

IOOC task teams made several major accomplishments. These teams are designed to provide subject matter expertise on a particular ocean observing topic. The task teams are an instrument for the committee to take on ocean observing issues that require more time than allocated in the bimonthly meetings. The IOOC supported three task teams during the reporting period: Metrics for Ocean Observing Systems, Biology-Integrating Core to Essential Variables (Bio-ICE), and Ocean Societal Indicators (OSI). IOOC leadership and staff also supported past task teams which have been transformed into community efforts such as the Underwater Glider User Group and the Animal Telemetry Network.

In addition to coordinating the IOOC Task Teams and community efforts, staff planned and executed OceanObs?19, part of a decadal conference series, which was held September 16-20, 2019 in Honolulu, Hawaii. OceanObs?19 galvanized over 1500 members of the global ocean observing community to investigate how the community meets future user needs (information), improves the delivery of products across the globe (interoperability), advances technology and services (innovation), and balances needs, capabilities, and knowledge worldwide (integration).

The Metrics for Ocean Observing Systems Task Team helps monitor and evaluate the status of U.S. observing activities at-large, which can then be used to assess IOOS and determine how adjustments to smaller programs can improve the system. These metrics should reflect indicators related to essential observing variables (EOVs)?physical, chemical, or biological?to help understand how well elements of the ocean domain are observed in time and space, determine vulnerabilities and opportunities in observing systems, and inform management and policy decisions to promote oceanographic research and operations. 
The Biology-Integrating Core to Essential Variables (Bio-ICE) Task Team will help advance the integration of biological observations from local, regional and federal sources using best practices to inform national needs and ultimately feed seamlessly into the Global Ocean Observing System, as appropriate. To accomplish this goal the task team will focus on marine mammals and corals, to: 1) Reconcile the IOOS core biological variables with GOOS Essential Ocean Variables (EOVs) and the Group on Earth Observations? Essential Biodiversity Variables (EBVs), identifying where there are clear synergies in terms of spatial and temporal observing requirements and existing observation infrastructure and delivery including best practices/standards. 2) Identify and improve pathways for data flow for observations of these variables from both the Regional Associations and Federal sources into IOOS. Focus will be on identifying and implementing best practices surrounding standardized data collection and delivery adhering to the FAIR and CARE data principles. 
The Ocean Societal Indicators (OSI) Task Team is seeking to increase our understanding of ocean and coastal systems and to improve science-based products and services for decision-making. The team will accomplish these objectives by leveraging existing observing programs that are conducting integrated observations (e.g. plankton/fish) to include socioeconomic and sociocultural indicators. Activities described in this scope of work will be consistent with the outcomes OceanObs?19, the UN Decade for Ocean Science and Sustainable Development, and the UN Sustainable Development Goals. 
Underwater Glider User Group (UG2) is a product of the IOOC Glider Task Team and their community convenings. This user group was developed as a community-based coalition aimed at bolstering scientific collaboration and information/resource sharing for glider operators, data users, manufacturers, academia, and government agencies.
The Animal Telemetry Network (ATN) structure was initially developed though the past IOOC ATN Task Team. Now, the ATN has become a fully integrated project under the U.S. IOOS. The operational ATN provides a mechanism to facilitate and empower an alliance among Federal, industry, academic, state, local, tribal, and non‐Federal organizations to coordinate aquatic animal telemetry infrastructure and operations.
OceanObs?19 resulted in an extensive list of recommendations which feed into a Living Action Plan and a host of Community White Papers outlining the priorities for the next decade, opportunities for strengthening end-user engagement, and concepts for better integration of global ocean observing.


In general, Ocean Leadership served as the neutral source for analyses and briefs and provided full-time professional project management of the Interagency Ocean Observation Committee (IOOC).  Ocean Leadership?s staff completed actions under the White House Subcommittee on Ocean Science and Technology (SOST), fulfilled executive and congressional IOOC mandates, and addressed some of the growing challenges facing the ocean science and technology community.
